The teacher drones on. Minnie doodles listlessly. A note lands on her desk. It reads: Write me a note. Minnie look around. Behind her, a very handsome boy with great hair, junior named RICKY WASSERMAN, 17, winks. Minnie drops the note back on Ricky’s desk. He unfurls it reading: A basic pancake recipe includes water, flour, ba powder, sugar and eggs. COOL ENGLISH TEACHER (CONT’D) Holden’s attitude toward homosexuals is called into question... The note drops back on Minnie’s desk: Madame, my heart contains nothing but admiration for you. The bell rings, Minnie gathers her things. Ricky and his friend ARNIE, another junior, blond and tall and preppy, surround her desk.  24.

dialogues.speaker: ARNIE
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to this bullshit artist. You should probably write notes to me.

dialogues.text: I see that. Angelica Houston is incredibly beautiful. Ricky flashes a winning smile. Minnie is flattered, and m Moments later, a long-haired slacker boy named CHUCK, 16, with a skateboard under his arm, approaches.

dialogues.text: What did they want?

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE

dialogues.text: Tweedle Dee and Tweedle Dipshit. They watch Ricky and Arnie leave.

dialogues.speaker: COOL ENGLISH TEACHER
dialogues.text: Ms. Goetze - next time I expect some more participation from you, I know you did the reading. Minnie nods reluctantly on her way out.

dialogues.speaker: FOOTAGE OF THE PATTY HEARST TRIAL 33
dialogues.text: Patty Hearst being sentenced. INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - THE LIVING ROOM - EARLY EVENING 34 Minnie comes in from school to find Monroe and Charlotte smoking a joint, and drinking around the coffee table as though nothing has happened.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: I just think it’s barbaric that she was found guilty! Even if she knew what she was doing in that bank - she was still a prisoner... Minnie turns on the TV, looking to Monroe to see if he’s going to acknowledge her. He doesn’t. She stares at him. CHARLOTTE (CONT’D) ..-Kidnapped, raped! Come on. She’s a victim!

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: (grasping) I don’t know. I guess it does seem kinda counter-progressive or something.  35 26. Monroe takes a long drag. He looks between Minnie and Charlotte, on either side. Minnie turns up the TV volume.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: (loudly over the TV) It’s bullshit. It’s fascist, misogynistic bullshit. You need to pay more attention to this stuff. Read the paper every once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you've said that. Charlotte shoots the rest of her drink, and exits for a refill. Monroe, unsure, finally decides to follow Charlot into the kitchen. As he passes behind Minnie, he reaches and tickles her neck. She slaps his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Don’t.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Turn down the volume, bucko. Monroe exits to the kitchen, Minnie seething. From the kitchen, she can hear Charlotte’s giggles. Minnie sinks i the couch.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 35 Minnie stands in front of her mirror, wrapped in a towel. pulls the picture Monroe took of her after their first ti out from her pocket and slides it into the edge of the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (earnest asking) What’s the point of living if nobody loves you? Nobody sees you? Nobody touches you? She drops her towel and stands naked. She compares the picture with her face in the mirror. And looks at her bod  Pink (01/08/2014) 27.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wish I were older than I am. It feels like there are little weights hanging from my heart that swing and tug every time I move, every time the wind blows.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK TO
dialogues.text: 36 INT. MONROE’S APARTMENT - DAY 36 Minnie and Monroe’s faces are close together.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: What’s your favorite color?

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Blue? Why are you asking me such stupid questions?

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: 37 INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 37 Minnie is still in front of the mirror, looking at her fa

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I want someone to be so totally in love with me that they would feel like they would die if I were gone. She looks at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Minnie, come on. Monroe rolls off of her. Minnie stares at the ceiling, bl balled. She climbs on top of his back, but he’s already falling asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Minnie-

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: But, I don’t want it to stop. Monroe falls asleep. Minnie stares at the ceiling, confus and frustrated and alone and blue-balled.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have no one to talk with about this highly complicated matter... INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - DAY 39 Minnie and Charlotte sit at the table, eating peanut-butt and jelly sandwiches and not talking.  Blue (12/17/2013) 29,

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-If my mother wasn’t involved with Monroe she could give me all the advice in the world.

dialogues.text: Kimmie is so white trash, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Boys love Kimmie.

dialogues.text: Aren’t you afraid she’1ll find out about you and Monroe? What if they get married? It’s so sick. Kimmie loves the drama.

dialogues.text: Blue (12/17/2013) 30. 4l INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS 41 Minnie and Charlotte are still eating their sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: I guess Kimmie has a good body.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Honestly, I feel like my mom is just worried that I don’t have a boyfriend. I mean, I don’t think she wants me to get pregnant like she did when she was my age, but...

dialogues.text: Obviously I can’t tell her about... you know. What am I going to say? “Mom, I’m sleeping with your boyfriend”?

dialogues.text: 43 INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS 43 Minnie stares at Charlotte intently. They are still eatin sandwiches.

dialogues.text: I don’t know what your problem is, Minnie. I would think you would be more into boys. Even Gretel has a boyfriend. (MORE )

dialogues.text: I mean he’s just that little short Italian boy from her class but still. Don’t you like anybody? You can tell me. There is a long pause. Minnie wants to tell her mom more anything. Instead, she shoves a big bite of her sandwich her mouth. CHARLOTTE (CONT’D) God, when I was in high school, the boys were all over me...

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Like... my dad? Charlotte is surprised Minnie is bringing him up, but goe with the memory.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Your dad and I were crazy about each other. He wasn’t so messed up back then. Hadn’t ever even smoked pot. He was just a wannabe artist with a fuck-the- world attitude. And he rode a Triumph Blackbird. Have I ever told you about that? Fuck, that was fantastic! Minnie doesn’t dare move. CHARLOTTE (CONT’D) My parents hated him. It was so hot. I knew I could call him any time day or night and he would ride that beautiful machine over to my house and rescue me. And I’d hold onto his waist, and scream! God, that boy... Charlotte lets out a languished sigh, gets up and starts clearing the dishes. She shakes away the memory. CHARLOTTE (CONT’D) You know, you aren’t always going to have that body, Min. I know it’s not exactly feminist to say, but I think you'd be happier if you put yourself out there a bit - a little make-up, a skirt every once in a while, jesus. Get a little attention. You have a kind of power, you just don’t know it yet.  44 45 Blue (12/17/2013) 32. Minnie stares at her mom’s butt as she scrapes their plat into the trash. This resonates with Minnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the rock.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Maybe I‘1l tell her when we’re both old and grey, and Monroe is cold in his grave, ya know?

dialogues.speaker: KIMMIE
dialogues.text: (totally distracted) Do you think I should start ironing my hair straight? Or do you think it’s kinda classic like this? Minnie looks at her, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have no one to talk to!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Minnie looks through the comic books listlessly.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .+-Maybe I should just ignore everything. But I like sex. I want to get laid right now. I really like getting fucked. Does everyone think about fucking as much as I do? She sees a nerdy boy looking at comic books and imagines penis, animated and wagging, on top of his pants.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: ...-Am I a sexed-up freak or something? Minnie hears a commotion coming from the back of the stor ALINE KOMINSKY, a bad-ass comic book artist, is doing a signing. A group of comic book fans are lined up, enthral Minnie peeks over the crowd and gets a glimpse of Aline- about the coolest woman she’s ever seen - she’s in awe. Minnie approaches the OLD HIPPIE behind the register, bal with a ponytail and a beard. He notices Minnie staring.  46 47 33.

dialogues.speaker: OLD HIPPIE
dialogues.text: Aline Kominsky - “The Bunch”. She’s good shit, man. He hands her “Twisted Sisters”, a comic book with a woman sitting on the toilet on the cover. The woman turns to Mi and winks. Minnie smiles to herself. This is something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minnie sits drawing in a booth, Aline Kominsky’s comic bo open in front of her. She traces one of Aline’s drawings.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I've decided Aline Kominsky is my favorite cartoonist. Minnie imagines an animated version of ALINE KOMINSKY, beautiful and rough with a big ass, working intently at a drawing table. Minnie watches her.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She must be beautiful and work all the time, at a little drawing table, with R. Crumb nearby at his drawing table. A COMIC R. CRUMB, as he draws himself, works nearby.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Everyone thinks he’s the brilliant one but I bet she gives him all of his ideas. And they talk about their pens and other equipment. The comic figures mingle with each other, laughing and looking at their artwork. Aline sparkles. INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - THE LIVING ROOM - EVENING 47 Minnie enters - the house has been tidied. A colorful afg is folded neatly and slung over the couch. There is music playing on the record player, and the table is set for tw with a table cloth and candles. Minnie hears her mom loud crying from the kitchen. She shoots Gretel a look, who shrugs, a little scared, and goes back to her book. Minni motions for Gretel to go to her. Gretel shakes her head l “hell no!”. Minnie tip-toes to the doorway and watches he mom, dressed in a skirt and heels, sitting on a stool in kitchen, head in her hands, sobbing loudly.  48 49 50 Blue (12/17/2013) 34. Some peas boil over on the stove. Minnie doesn’t move, sh just watches, out of sight, terrified and guilty. INT. MINNIE’S BEDROOM —- CONTINUOUS 48 Minnie rushes into her room, kicking her chair and stuff she goes.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I feel like all of Monroe’s excuses not to come over here are excuses not to see me. But my mom thinks it’s about her. Minnie pulls out a piece of paper and starts scribbling.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Monroe. I know you think I’m fat. But I don’t care because I know that black guys the world over... EXT. MONROE’S CAR - IN FRONT OF HIS HOUSE - EVENING 49 Monroe arrives at his car and finds the note pinned under windshield wiper. He reads.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -..and also Italian construction workers and wetbacks and old men and also some lesbians like fat girls even if you don't, so there. Love, Little Minnie. Monroe rolls his eyes, and crumples the letter. He shoves in his pocket. INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - A DIFFERENT DAY 50 The phone rings and Minnie leaps for it.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? PASCAL’S VOICE Minnie.  35.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: (disappointed, into phone) Pascal. PASCAL’S VOICE Don’t sound so excited.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Sorry. PASCAL’S VOICE Did you get your biology test back?

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: B-minus. PASCAL’S VOICE Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: How’s New York?

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: 51 INT. PASCAL’S HOUSE - EVENING 51 Pascal, a professorial man, sits at a small but pretentio desk in his study in New York.

dialogues.speaker: PASCAL
dialogues.text: (into phone) Stimulating. Intellectually and otherwise. You would love it here. The libraries alone elevate it far above San Francisco. MINNIE’S VOICE Sounds cool.

dialogues.speaker: PASCAL
dialogues.text: (into phone) You know that if you ever decide that you want to broaden your horizons, Minnie - New York is a great place for a young lady. You could live with me. I was your surrogate father for many years and that doesn’t end just because your mother and I are no longer legally bound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 52 Minnie draws while she balances the phone on her ear. In notebook are many tracings she’s done of Aline Kominsky’s comic book cover. PASCAL’S VOICE What are you reading nowadays?

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Ummm. Searching for Mr. Goodbar. Did you ever finish it? PASCAL’S VOICE Please, that inflammatory fiction? I just finished The Final Days about the end of Nixon’s administration. It’s darkly fascinating to witness how well he fares while his dreams crash around him.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: I’m reading some cool comic books too.

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: 53 INT. PASCAL’S HOUSE - EVENING 53

dialogues.speaker: PASCAL
dialogues.text: (into phone) Well, that’s a waste of a good mind. I’m sending you a book on flies. (then) So... where’s your mother? MINNIE’S VOICE I don’t know. She’s not back from work yet.

dialogues.speaker: PASCAL
dialogues.text: (into phone) Is she coming home tonight? MINNIE’S VOICE I guess. She didn’t say she wasn’t. She usually finishes at the library at 6.  37.

dialogues.speaker: PASCAL
dialogues.text: (into phone) Who’s she going out with these days?

dialogues.speaker: WITH
dialogues.text: 54 MINNIE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 54 Minnie is drawing.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t say she was going out with anyone! You don’t even listen to me, Pascal. PASCAL’S VOICE That’s not true, Minnie.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Besides, mom isn’t even partying really. She’s like a monk. Or a nun or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK TO
dialogues.text: 55 INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - THE LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 55 Charlotte and her friends sit around in the dark passing joint and sniffing cocaine. BURT, a stoned guy in his 40s with a mustache, and MICHAEL COCAINE, a 45 year old lawye with a coke habit, mingle. ANDREA, late 20s, Charlotte’s slightly dumb friend, turns to Michael Cocaine, high:

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Wait, is this why they call you Michael Cocaine? Everyone starts laughing.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: 56 INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 56 Minnie holds the phone reluctantly to her ear. PASCAL’S VOICE Well, don’t tell her I was asking about her....  57 Pink (01/08/2014) 38. His voice fades out. Minnie draws herself, as a distorted cartoon. Animated Minnie begins to move on the page, as s draws.

dialogues.speaker: BEGIN IMAGINING
dialogues.text: Animated Minnie, with hairy legs, strides through San Francisco, boldly.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Aline Kominsky, Hello. My name is Minnie and I am an aspiring cartoonist. Animated Minnie meets different boys along her journey. S keeps walking, morphing. Sometimes she has big thighs, sometimes her head is very small. Sometimes her breasts b from her shirt. She keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I am a huge fan of yours. Most cartoons don't amuse me at all, but I love yours. I've just completed my first real comic. It's only one page. It's about walking around in the city. I used India Ink but I wasn't sure what kind of paper to use. What do you use? With admiration, Minnie Goetze. Animated Minnie disappears into the city.

dialogues.speaker: END IMAGINING
dialogues.text: INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - KITCHEN/LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 57 Minnie and Gretel sit eating a sad dinner together. Minni pokes at her peas on her plate, despondent. Gretel sits across from her, filing her nails.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It stirs up a kind of frustrated passion in my heart to think of Monroe sometimes, to think about him out with my mother.

dialogues.speaker: GRETEL
dialogues.text: Mom said I could go to a boy/girl party on Saturday at Lindsay's. Anthony's taking me.

dialogues.speaker: GRETEL

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Who, Kimmie? stares Minnie in the eyes and starts to tear up. does too.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: KIMMIE

dialogues.text: Fair? You fucked my step-dad! A light turns on in the big house they’re in front of.  96. FRANKIE’S VOICE Come on, girls.

dialogues.text: Hey, no no no. This isn’t happening. You can’t do this here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Shit, bitches. Frankie holds the girls apart, who yell over him.  97.

dialogues.text: I’m a slut? You’re a FUCKING LESBIAN WHORE, Minnie!

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: She fucked my step-dad!

dialogues.speaker: WORSE
dialogues.text: Minnie struggles to get away from Frankie who is holding back, storms off.

dialogues.speaker: KIMMIE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE

dialogues.text: Hey, hey. Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Stop it, Chuck! She takes off quickly, he follows.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Minnie! What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: No! I don’t want to leave you alone. He grabs her shoulder.  Blue (12/17/2013) 98.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Let go of me, Chuck! Kimmie is a fucking bitch.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Who cares about her? You’re so much... smarter and better than her. I never understood why she was your friend, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Oh - I see how you look at her. You want to fuck her, like everyone else!

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: No, I don’t. How can you say that? It’s so obvious that I like you. If I wanted to fuck anyone, it would be you- I’m not saying I wanna- shit. Minnie doesn’t stop walking quicbvkly but is thrown.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Well, then you’re an idiot. I’m fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: No, you're not. You’re amazing.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: I am fucked up. I am! I AM! You don’t know anything about me. You don’t know shit. Just leave me alone, Chuck. Fuck you, you Minnie takes off. He doesn’t follow. He is so disappointe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud rock music. Minnie moves through the crowd, scanning Minnie approaches a group smoking. She sees who she was looking for. She beelines for Tabatha, who spins around, surprised and happy to see Minnie.

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA
dialogues.text: Hey truck driver. Minnie kisses her hard. Tabatha’s friends share a look.  Blue (12/17/2013) 99.

dialogues.speaker: LESBIAN HOUSE PARTY
dialogues.text: Minnie and Tabatha dance closely with each other, pushed between the sweaty bodies. Minnie dances hard, trying to forget her life. Tabatha touches Minnie’s body as she mov Tabatha and Minnie snort a line, letting the world fall a Tabatha and Minnie make love. Body parts everywhere: curv and delicate limbs entwined. Tabatha kisses Minnie. INT. MIKE’S APARTMENT BUILDING - HALLWAY - NIGHT 119 Tabatha pulls Minnie, through the dirty hallway. Minnie giggles, unaware.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Who is Mike again?

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA
dialogues.text: My friend. You met him last night. He’s cool. Minnie is slowing to a crawl, exhausted and moving slow. leans against a wall, stopping.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: He has so many stairs. I want to go back to bed. Tabatha leans into Minnie, kissing her.

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA
dialogues.text: We will, you cute little thing. We just are making this one stop. Like we talked about, okay?

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Tabatha kisses Minnie’s neck as she talks.

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA
dialogues.text: Mike won't stop asking about you. So I said we’d come by. He has really good ‘ludes.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Oh great.

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA
dialogues.text: You like that? Don’t I know how to take care of my girl?  100.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: (smiling at the reference) Yes. I’m hungry though. Tabatha kisses Minnie, touching her face and body.

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA
dialogues.text: Everybody thinks you’re sexy. Your eyes, and that ass. It’s a good thing I’m not insecure. Otherwise I might start feeling all possessive and shit.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA
dialogues.text: Yeah. With boys like Mike lusting after you. But I know it’s not a big deal. I’m not uptight, and you're not uptight, right?

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: What’s not a big deal?

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA
dialogues.text: It will be so quick. Men are easy. Over in a second. Minnie acts like she understands what Tabatha is saying. Tabatha’s tone changes: she’s desperate for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need you to do this for me. You're going to do this, right? For me, baby?

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA
dialogues.text: And then we’ll have a great night, just the two of us. Me and my girl? You wanna make me happy, don’t you? Minnie nods. Tabatha kisses her again, relaxing.

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good. You're doing good. (then, so charming) I’m falling hard for you, girl. Tabatha leads Minnie into the apartment.  120 121 Blue (12/17/2013) 101. INT. MIKE’S APARTMENT —- CONTINUOUS 120 The apartment is drab but fine. Mike, 25 and not horrible looking, is in the kitchen frying something on the stove, with his shirt off. Tabatha talks in whispers to Mike, while Minnie sits on t couch, nervous. Minnie looks to them, plotting.

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA
dialogues.text: (calling to Minnie) You hungry, baby? We’re gonna make you a grilled cheese. Minnie nods. Tabatha and Mike keep talking in hushed tone All sound cuts out except the sound of Minnie’s heartbeat push in on Minnie’s face: scared and in over her head. Tabatha looks to her, and gives a little wink. She can’t from this seat. She looks to the door and back to Tabatha Her eyes fill with tears. How did she get here? Suddenly Minnie beelines for the door.

dialogues.speaker: TABATHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey- She runs like her life depends on it, down the many steps into the street and down the block. EXT. MIKE’S APARTMENT BUILDING - CONTINUOUS 121 Minnie runs and runs, crying and shaking until she hits a corner with a phone booth, where she lets out a wail. Out energy, out of ideas, she slumps down into the booth and closes the door, crouching with nowhere to go. Cars drive by. The stars are out. Minnie is alone. She we

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nobody loves me. She curls up at the bottom of the phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Maybe nobody will ever love me. Maybe there’re only a few people in the whole world who are actually loved - the lucky fucks. And the rest of us walk through the world like ghosts, with no one to see us or care about us. Alone forever.  122 123 124 102. Over-used prostitutes saunter up to cars but get little action. Kids sleep in dark doorways. Minnie wimpers. She out of options.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - THE LIVING ROOM - LATE NIGHT 122 Minnie makes a loud racket as she enters the house, knock over a lamp on her way in.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Fuck. She waits, but nobody stirs. She looks around at her hous ashtrays filled with cigarettes litter the dark apartment INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - BATHROOM - CONTINUOUS 123 Minnie throws up violently in the toilet. She stands up, wiping her mouth barely. She drinks from the faucet. She swings open the medicine cabinet and finds one of her mom’s prescription bottles labeled “Vicodin”. She pours them all into her hand. Contemplates. She pops one into her mouth, puts the rest back, and drops the bottle into her pocket. She closes th cabinet and takes a look at her fucked up face in the mir Not liking what she sees, she swings the mirror away, alm breaking it. INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM —- MOMENTS LATER 124 Minnie clicks on the light in her room. Her bed is still unmade. A drawing of Monroe that she did is pinned on her wall. She rips it off, and kicks some of her other belongings. She plops on her bed, then feels something under hear hea her pillow. It’s a letter addressed to her. She almost th it on the floor, but then she opens it. ALINE KOMINSKY’S VOICE Dear Minnie. Thank you for your letter. Minnie stirs, realizing it’s from Aline.  125 103. ALINE KOMINSKY'’S VOICE (CONT’D) It is refreshing to receive a letter from a girl because most letters I get are from greasy fan boys who think that I’m cute. I tend not to write back to them. Keep drawing those comics. Keep drawing anything you can. Just keep drawing. Oh, and I use Indian Ink as well. Love, Aline Kominsky. Minnie lies back - the weight of everything’s she’s gone through hitting her. She cries. This hurts so much. Someo stirs in the living room. GRETEL’S VOICE Hello? INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER 125 Minnie peeks out of her door and sees Gretel looking arou at the tipped over lamp. Gretel spots Minnie and runs to jumping on her, knocking them both to the ground. They ho each other. Just then Charlotte comes in the front door, her big coat and hat. She looks exhausted. Charlotte stares at Minnie. Minnie meets her eye, unsure how her mom will react. Charlotte shakes her head - she i once relieved and angry.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Goddamnit Minnie.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Gretel holds onto Minnie’s legs, not letting go. Charlott approaches, slaps her across the face, and then grabs her into a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Do you know how worried we were? We looked for you everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Of course! I’ve been out all night. I’ve been out every night since you left, looking for you. I thought you were dead.  104. Minnie collapses into her mother’s arms, relieved to be h They are silent for a long time. Minnie cries. The sun st to rise.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, mom, I’m so-

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Shhh. It’s alright, Min. It’s over. Minnie cries in her mother’s arms, Charlotte cries too.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: I wanted to tell you about Monroe, I really did-

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: (she can’t take it) Stop it, no.

dialogues.speaker: DON'T.
dialogues.text: Minnie looks to her mom. Charlotte can’t talk about this. CHARLOTTE (CONT’D) I don’t want to talk about it. Ever. You're home. It’s over. That’s all I care about. Minnie sees her mother clearly for the first time. Denial the only way forward.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: I gotta go to bed. Charlotte pats Minnie’s face, exits to her room, exhauste Minnie looks to Gretel. It’s just them. Like always.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: I’m hungry. Gretel nods.  126 127 128 Pink (01/08/2014) 105. INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - SUNRISE 126 Minnie pulls out a bowl, and bisquik. She beats some eggs and mixes in the flour. She cooks pancakes, while Gretel looks on from the table. The sun comes up out the window, they eat. “She” by the Misfits, about Patty Hearst, plays. Video footage of Patty Hearst surrendering in Pleasanton, CA in 1977, and being taken into custody. The battle is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minnie walks down the street. Time has passed, she looks healthier. It’s a mirror of the opening sequence but she’ gone through so much. She passes people in the park, she looks at them with wisdom in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Did you ever go back to your preschool once you had gotten big and everything looked miniature? Like the chairs and the monkey bars - just much smaller than you remembered? She drops a letter in a mailbox. It’s addressed to Aline Kominsky. She sees Chuck walking down the street holding hands with a girl. They make eye-contact for a brief mome Minnie waves. He nods. That’s it. Minnie flips through the comic books in the store. She fi a few she likes. Minnie keeps walking down the street.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know nothing’s changed, but everything looks totally different to me now. INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - THE LIVING ROOM - LATER 128 Minnie sits in front of the TV, drawing while she watches She flips through the channels until she comes to The Mup Show. At some point Gretel comes in and sits down on the floor with a box of crackers. Fozzie is doing a bit about ventriloquism. They sit watching together. Minnie reaches into the box and grabs a cracker. The phone rings. Minnie picks it up.  129 106.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? PASCAL’S VOICE Minnie- it’s Pascal- Minnie hangs up. Goes back to watching TV with her sister

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minnie and Charlotte are in the crowded nightclub togethe They cheer for the band, as they enter the stage. Minnie looks at Charlotte, so happy and drunk.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My mom and I aren’t the same species. It’s not her fault. She thinks she needs a man to be happy. I don’t. Charlotte whoops and hollers for the band.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Everything that’s happened with Monroe, and Tabatha, and Pascal and my mom has probably fucked me up somewhere deep in my soul. But maybe it was worth it because I've realized some things: It’s not about who loves you. It’s all about liking yourself. Just liking yourself enough to keep living til the next day, and maybe the one after that. The guitarist from the band blows a kiss and Charlotte an she screams, lifting her arms in the air.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My mom has a new boyfriend. He’s an unusually nice guy. I hope she stays with him for a while. Charlotte grabs Minnie, dancing with her. She hands Minni her drink, but then adds:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: But just a sip. Charlotte winks. Minnie smiles. She looks to her mother - totally in her element.  130 131 Blue (12/17/2013) 107. He mom whistles at the band, and dances, happier than we' ever seen her. Minnie whistles too. CHARLOTTE (CONT’D) If his friends ask, we’re sisters, okay?

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’s not perfect, my ol’ mama, but she’s the only one I got. The band starts up a song, Minnie cheers. INT. MINNIE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT 130 Minnie sits on her bed, talking into her microphone.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: (into mic) This whole time it’s felt like I’m so precariously close to the edge, to the end... but really, my life has only just begun. A song comes on the radio that Minnie likes. She puts dow the microphone and dances like crazy, loving every moment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minnie sits on a low wall by the running path. She has a blanket laid out with xeroxed zines and drawings for sale She talks to a tourist.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: It's fifty cents but if you buy two drawings or one drawing and a zine, it’s 90 cents. But I don’t actually have a dime, so it would end up being the same price. The tourist hands her two quarters, humoring her, and tak drawing, walking away. Minnie enjoys the sun. Monroe jogs by, wearing his jogging outfit. He sees Minni and stops, but keeps jogging in place.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Minnie. Hi. Minnie jumps down.  108.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Are you here alone?

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: No, Gretel’s with me. She went to find a bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Oh. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: She had to pee. There is an awkward moment. Minnie jogs in place too.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So... you wanna buy a drawing? Or a ‘gine?

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Oh. No money. Jogging shorts and all.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: Here. Take this one. You can give the fifty cents to my mom the next time you see her. Monroe looks down at a small drawing of a transvestite wi hairy chest. It’s beautifully drawn. He hates it. Monroe smiles awkwardly. It is evident he wants to go.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (holding out her hand) Well, goodbye Monroe. He takes her hand and shakes it. She doesn’t hate him.

dialogues.speaker: MONROE
dialogues.text: Goodbye Minnie.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE
dialogues.text: (while holding his hand) I’m better than you, you son-of-a- bitch.  132 Pink (01/08/2014) 109. They drop hands, and Monroe jogs off, not sure of what to make of this. Minnie is left standing there with the wate and sun behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minnie and Gretel play in the water, chasing the waves as they go out. Minnie splashes Gretel, who laughs and splas her back.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is for all the girls when the have grown. The sun glistens on the water as we pull away from the sisters, who look like little girls playing on the beach.

dialogues.speaker: MINNIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Signing off, trusty Diary. Love, Minnie Goetze.G
